quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: What would be the point of an existence where you don’t create? That’s like the whole purpose of the human soul.
quotes.context: Core thesis for why he builds at all; a thematic spine for the whole film.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: We’re all slowly dying. I gotta make what I can.
quotes.context: A stark, memorable line that reframes the project as a race against time.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Making this game is honestly like scaling 50 Everests.
quotes.context: Conveys the scale of the undertaking in one vivid metaphor.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: If you want to finish a Mario 64 major hack, you need to be mentally ill. You cannot do it if you are not mentally ill.
quotes.context: Dark humor that communicates obsessive endurance and the cost of finishing.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: This all runs on real hardware. That’s the whole point.
quotes.context: The project’s credibility claim and technical north star.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: It is one of my conditions that it fits on a normal N64 cartridge. I’m not gonna go above 64 megabytes.
quotes.context: The defining constraint that shapes every department’s choices.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: If you go over 64 MB, are you really still making an N64 game? It just feels like cheating to me.
quotes.context: Explains the emotional meaning behind the cartridge-size rule.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I made a completely new collision system. I said, fuck Mario 64’s collision. It is unusable.
quotes.context: Signals a decisive break from the original engine to reach modern stability/feel.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: This is what the N64 games could have looked like. You were robbed.
quotes.context: Positions RTYI as an “alternate history” of what the hardware could do.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: In the final version, the way this is going to work is that there is not going to be any warps anymore. It is going to be seamless.
quotes.context: The headline promise: a connected island world rather than disconnected courses.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I am planning to be at 0%—like no Nintendo code at all.
quotes.context: Raises the stakes from “ROM hack” to near-total re-authorship.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: There comes a point at which you reduce friction so much that you lose the game’s purpose and soul. And it just turns into slop.
quotes.context: A trailer-ready ethos line: resisting “modernization” that kills the classic feel.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: This is guaranteed open source. I want people to be able to maintain this code base after I leave the scene, and I want other people to be able to make hacks off of my engine.
quotes.context: Legacy and community intent: RTYI as an engine meant to outlive him.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: When you make games it always starts really fun and eventually it turns into pure torture. That’s just the cycle of making games.
quotes.context: A clear framing of the emotional arc of long development.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Making decisions is like the most important thing of making a game. No matter how hard you work, if you don't make good decisions, your game's gonna be shit.
quotes.context: Leadership philosophy: taste and judgment over raw effort.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Designing something is not just about coming up with ideas; it’s about solving whatever problem you have in design.
quotes.context: Turns “creativity” into practical problem-solving—useful for process narration.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I think games should be about experiencing freedom… I don’t want the dev telling me, hey, do this, please.
quotes.context: Core player-experience philosophy that drives hub/world design.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I don't know how much freedom you should give players, and it should end when they ruin their playthrough for themselves.
quotes.context: Nuance: authored constraints as protection of the player’s experience.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: If there’s a bug in Mario 64 that you only encounter if you do it on purpose, I’ll leave it in the game. But if it can happen on accident, I’ll remove it.
quotes.context: A crisp rule for honoring the classic while removing accidental pain.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: You have to be very careful with the text you put, because players start out with some amount of patience left for your game… for a ROM hack, you can’t really go over your patience budget.
quotes.context: Practical wisdom about onboarding and “friction cost” in a volunteer audience.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I think making a game is all about designing a feeling that you want the player to have.
quotes.context: Emotion-first creative philosophy; plays well over gameplay montage.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: The point is: you think of an emotion, and then you think about how you can use the tools in your arsenal to evoke this emotion.
quotes.context: His method in one sentence—turn feelings into mechanics and spaces.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Players don’t realize that the only resource they truly have is their time.
quotes.context: A human-centered lens for difficulty, pacing, and respect for the player.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: This is a game, not a meme.
quotes.context: Tone/identity boundary: RTYI as a cohesive game, not a pile of jokes.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: This is not about logic. This is about cool. Rule of cool.
quotes.context: Art-direction north star for set pieces and spectacle.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Video games are not supposed to be chores!
quotes.context: Anti-grind manifesto; a clean heading for the “respect the player” segment.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I don’t want difficulty. I want excitement.
quotes.context: Mission statement for how challenge should feel in RTYI.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: We only need to fake it well enough that no one notices that it’s fake.
quotes.context: A perfect chapter card for N64-era illusion-making and optimization.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Pick your own difficulty.
quotes.context: Clean section header for optional risk and player agency.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Breaking that convention, that feels like breaking a promise to the player.
quotes.context: A chapter hook about respecting Mario 64’s language and expectations.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: The game gets done when it gets done.
quotes.context: Definitive stance against release-date pressure.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Developing video games is suffering.
quotes.context: A blunt title card for the cost-of-creation thread.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Item babysitting is the game design morphine.
quotes.context: Memorable phrasing for his stance against “escort/hold-item” design crutches.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Credits are mandatory on day one.
quotes.context: Values statement: attribution as a non-negotiable in modding collaboration.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: If your level is shit and people tell you it’s shit, you should still be happy that at least someone is telling you it’s shit.
quotes.context: Tough-love relationship to feedback; reveals resilience and ego management.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Guys, I’m good at programming. I’m not good with technology.
quotes.context: Disarming self-portrait while fighting tools; comic relief.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: MFs will never believe you how fucking hard it was to make this thing spin this way around.
quotes.context: Relatable frustration after a technical win; shows the hidden labor of polish.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I thought RAM on the N64 was infinite.
quotes.context: Comic line right after hitting memory limits; humanizes the engineering grind.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Act 1, he’s complaining. Act 2, he’s complaining. Act 3, there’s like a cutscene.
quotes.context: Funny story-structure pitch; shows how he thinks about tone and pacing.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I want it to be that, but for cowboys… so, a cowboyaboo.
quotes.context: A memorable joke that still communicates tone experimentation.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I watched playtesters play it and I realized this area fucking sucks.
quotes.context: Ruthless self-editing based on observation, not pride.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Every time the game takes control away from me, it just feels like a small kick to my balls.
quotes.context: Crude but clear: his obsession with player control and agency.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Every emulator is broken as fuck. I just have to pick one emulator and run with it.
quotes.context: Blunt reality check about compatibility and why testing explodes in complexity.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Gamers don’t look up.
quotes.context: A quick, funny truth that informs level readability and secret placement.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Every time someone asks, I add an extra day. We are now in 2035.
quotes.context: Recurring bit that captures release-date pressure and audience entitlement.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I’m not motivated at all, so there’s no motivation involved. I just do it.
quotes.context: Reveals his work psychology and how the project survives low-motivation days.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I do have a family now that I need to provide for, so I can’t just mess around with my time and do that. I have to make sensible decisions.
quotes.context: Adulthood and responsibility entering the creative equation.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I unfortunately cannot monetize this. I have to release it for free or I will get murdered.
quotes.context: Unfiltered economic/legal reality of Nintendo-adjacent fan work.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: They’ve already taken down 70 of my videos… I will have to release a copyright-free version. That is gonna happen and you know it.
quotes.context: Escalation: takedowns force a parallel “safe” release plan.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Oh shit, it is Mario Day. It’s a RAM overflow—we’re out of memory.
quotes.context: A live setback: hard limits colliding with momentum in real time.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I as a male have gotten a rape threat. That’s insane. That’s never happened to me before.
quotes.context: Rare vulnerability about harassment and the cost of public development.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: They asked me to verify my identity three months ago… and now they just closed my account basically.
quotes.context: Operations crisis (accounts/payments) intruding on the project’s stability.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: We’re going to have a kid in like two months. That’s the birth date.
quotes.context: A time-stamped life event that reshapes schedule and stakes.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Now that I have a child, I need to make more money… it also means I might have to sell out a little bit, unfortunately.
quotes.context: Sustainability pressure and the ethical tension of “making it work.”

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: To me, the anxiety of working on 64 Land is a blur in my memory. I don't remember that I made that game. It's like someone else took possession of my body and made it.
quotes.context: Heavy reflection on stress and dissociation from past crunch.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: This is what happens when you keep changing the engine, all the levels just break.
quotes.context: The hidden tax of innovation: progress creates regressions everywhere.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: We’re missing one kilobyte of RAM… This is a quarter of a texture.
quotes.context: Heartbreakingly small limit with huge consequences—classic N64-era pain.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: Spending four years alone in a room without talking kind of murdered that. But I had the romhack to make, so it was worth it.
quotes.context: Personal cost of obsession: isolation framed as the price of finishing.

quotes.speaker: Kaze
quotes.quote: I wouldn’t want to put out a game that I myself would refuse to play.
quotes.context: Quality as self-respect; explains why he keeps reworking instead of shipping.
